The Sutra of the Fierce Contemplation Brahmins, Sutra 11 of the Fierce Contemplation Brahmins
Hears this sort of:

The Buddha was in the ÅšÄkya country, under the Bodhi tree in Kapilavastu, with five hundred bhiká¹£us, all arhats, who had accomplished what was to be done, had put down the heavy burden, had crossed over by hearing the meaning, and had ended rebirth in the womb.
At that time, the earth gods and wondrous heavens from the ten directions came to where the Buddha was, wanting to see the honored virtue and the assembly of bhiká¹£us.
At that time, the Four Heavenly Kings said to each other:
Do the students know that the Buddha is under the Bodhi tree in Kapilavastu in the ÅšÄkya country, with five hundred true people?
Moreover, the earth gods and wondrous heavens from the ten directions have all come to pay homage to the Buddha, wanting to see the honored spiritual power and the bhiká¹£us.
Why don't we go now to see his spiritual power?

The Four Heavenly Kings then flew down from the seventh heaven, in the time it takes for a strong man to bend and extend his arm, and arrived at the Buddha's side. Not far from the Venerable One, they all went to pay homage to the Buddha and the assembly of monks, and each sat in their seat.
One Brahma Heaven, having sat down, spoke a verse, saying:
Now there is a great assembly in the grove, coming to see the Venerable One, all divine beings.
Now I have come to listen to the Dharma, wishing to see the assembly of the utmost.
A second Brahma Heaven, having just sat down, spoke a verse, saying:
In this study, one should restrain the mind, straightforwardly practicing and knowing the body is correct,
Like a charioteer skillfully controlling the two reins, guarding the eye faculty and practicing the mind of awakening.
A third Brahma Heaven, having sat down, spoke a verse, saying:
Severing the seven and subduing the six heretical bonds, the mind is attached to cessation like an iron root,
Abandoning worldly views, pure and spotless, with the wisdom eye, the bright mind is collected.
A fourth Brahma Heaven, having sat down, spoke a verse, saying:
By entrusting oneself to the Bright Honored One, one will never be born into evil darkness,
After abandoning the human form and being reborn, one will receive a heavenly body and gradually be free from suffering.
At that time, among the assembly, there was a brahman named Fierce Contemplation, who also had doubts in the great assembly.

The Buddha knew the doubts that arose in the mind of the brahman Fierce Contemplation, and at that time he transformed into a Buddha, with an upright and incomparably handsome appearance, pleasing to behold, with the thirty-two marks of a great man, a golden complexion, and light, wearing the great robe as described above.
He then faced the Buddha with palms joined, praising in verse:
Each person thinks of him and also knows, each wishing to surpass with wisdom that can be spoken,
There is one who can know and exhaust this Dharma, seeking everywhere without relying on understanding.
Taking this, one is born and transformed, foolishly considering him to be my good wisdom,
Speaking sincerely, what is said is equal, all of this is good speech.
Not knowing that dharmas are non-existent, darkness follows that ignorance,
In darkness, all feelings are ignorant, what is thought and practiced all has that existence.
First, thinking of the past, speaking of practice, wisdom has already purified the mind and thoughts are good,
This is all not hoping for ignorance to decrease, all that is thought and attached is cessation of intention.
I do not rely on all of this, the foolish can practice and pull each other along.
Seeing oneself as careful and true, oneself is deluded and again accepts that,
Speaking of the Dharma oneself, unsurpassed, using emptiness to greedily come and steal.
Already eight kinds of darkness pull each other into darkness, why does the learner not speak of one?
One truth exhausts the two kinds of existence and non-existence, knowing this truth is non-inverted,
It is said that not exhausting the truth follows the mind, therefore the learner does not speak of one.
Which truth is the other not spoken of?
Whom should one believe to speak of the remainder?ğŸ”½If there is a remainder of truth, from where does it come?
From what does the consciousness of the mind arise?
If consciousness is not left over, what else can be said to be left over?
What is seen by the eyes is grasped as desirable, if consciousness deceives, it exhausts both dharmas.
Hearing, seeing, precepts, intentions, and practices, grasping desires, changing, and disputing views.
Stopping calculations, observing what is shameful?
Therefore, delusion again bestows them.
From what delusion is bestowed upon them?
Their adornments are good for me.
Then, having proclaimed oneself as a good speaker, if there is a dispute, one gives rise to resentment towards them,
Firmly holding wrong views, expecting to serve as a teacher, with perverse intentions, full of deceit and adornments.
Always fearing that words will not reach, I always observe and see that this is an ascetic,
Seeing their true wrong views, hiding shame,
Having fully known and distinguished, delusion is completely without the practice of good intentions,
This is called abiding in truth and then speaking, all can purify one's own Dharma.
Thus, grasping leads to confusion and change, and one's own causes and conditions become attached and defiled.
From different practices, one attains liberation and purity, but even though it is pure, it does not reach the end.
When the non-Buddhist practitioners hear this, they become complacent, and their greed and self-importance increase.

They defend their own importance and solidity against greed, so what kind of delusion would they speak of?ğŸ”½Even though they are taught the Dharma, they are not yet pure, and give rise to self-importance and arrogance.
Dwelling in the truth, the Shakya clan is in control, and even in the past there was confusion.
Abandoning all thoughts of what is done, the wonderful one does not do what is done.
After the Buddha finished speaking this Sutra of Meaning and Fulfillment, the bhikshus were all delighted.
The Sutra of the Brahman Dharmagupta, Chapter 12, thus have I heard:

The Buddha was in the Shakya country, under the Bodhi tree in Kapilavastu, together with five hundred bhikshus, all of whom were arhats who had accomplished what needed to be done, laid down the heavy burden, realized the truth for themselves, and ended the cycle of birth and death.

The four Brahmas then sat down and spoke a verse, saying:

At that time, in the assembly there was a brahman named Dharma Contemplation, who was also in the great assembly.
Based on his views, he saw that those who attain nirvana have a body, and thus he had doubts about the causes and conditions of the mind.

The Buddha knew that the brahmin had doubts, and at that time he transformed into a Buddha, with an incomparably upright and handsome appearance, and a majestic bearing that delighted all who saw him. He then faced the Buddha with palms joined and praised him in verse, saying:

All of them are also light to me, and may also lead to good conditions.
Knowing a little, having shame, disputing, changing the original, speaking of two fruits,
Seeing this, abandoning the original, wishing to contemplate, peacefully without change.
All are level, also like the earth, this has never been seen as equal,
From what inequality is the same?
Seeing, hearing, speaking, do not change.
Dwelling in attachment, this multitude is detestable, what can be seen, heard, and thought of,
Who is the bright one who rains down purity?
Love not yet removed, body after body.
With precepts, subduing offenses and purifying, practicing truth and auspiciousness, already fully abiding,
Herein, would rather pass through to purity, able to fear the world being in good teachings.
Already detached from truth, seeking practice again, all from causes and conditions of offenses,
Also like speaking of power, seeking purity, losing one's own meaning and suffering of birth and death,
Practicing power and seeking, also not speaking, eyes like practice and also contemplating,
Birth and death endless from this, such wisdom also like speaking.
Precepts, their practice all abandoning, offenses and blessings also abandoning and going far,
Purity and defilement not thinking of awakening, without taint and impurity, pure and compassionate acceptance.
Cultivating this Dharma, crossing over that one, speaking of no practice is far deception,
Accepting this, then increasing change, each cause and condition, worldly false gain.
One's own Dharma then considered complete, seeing that Dharma, questioned for leakage,
Engaging in unequal conduct, turning against each other, seeing their own conduct as unstained.
Whatever is said is feared to be deceptive, there is no benefit in the Dharma,
without wisdom, the assembly speaks of purity differently, attached to their own views, each firmly abiding.
Each venerating the Dharma as heard and abiding, expounding as understood, teaching as one's own master,

Speaking thus, they also say, One view falls from purity,

Attached to what is grasped, seeking liberation, recollecting what is believed without abiding,

Observing the world, people see names and forms, with their wisdom, knowing as they receive,

Having wisdom and practice, without accumulation, knowing and seeing correctly to attain,
Seeing without fault is practicing this Dharma, crossing over confusion and not receiving again.
The mind of wisdom reaches nowhere, not seeing the solid consciousness that is aware,
Like closing and controlling attachments, only practicing observation without grasping differences.
The honored one cuts off worldly acceptance and grasping, grasping and birth should not be solid,
Calm and also confused, in observation and abandonment, being in this evil, pitying ordinary people.
Discarding the old and forming the new, not creating, having no desires, what is there to be attached to?
Liberated from evil, with faith and courage, crossing over, already liberated from the world and non-world.
All dharmas are without doubt, all seeing and hearing, what is there to think?
Abandoning the heavy burden, the honored one is rightly liberated, not wishing to pass beyond, always coming to see.

'The great general with seven heads, will certainly repay heavy kindness.

Now I pay homage to the Right Enlightenment, and think of the Dharma and return to the honored Dharma.

From lack of compassion comes fear. People should listen to the wise in every generation.
I now wish to speak of meaning that may be hurtful. What I have learned is to abandon fear.
The suffering of transmigration is all of the people of the world, like dry water cutting off the flow of fish,
Living in suffering, giving rise to the intention to harm, replacing their fear with the joy of delusion.
All worlds are thus burned, all ten directions are in chaos and unstable,
Arrogant and not abandoning love, not seeing, thus holding deluded thoughts.
Do not create bonds seeking painful darkness, I observe all minds are not joyful,
They bring about painful views and thorns, seeing difficulties is hard to endure.
From thorns pain is firm and not abandoned, carrying thorns one runs all over the world,
The honored one just sees the painful thorn pulled out, suffering does not think and does not run again.
The world also has all that should not be accepted, wrong confusion should be abandoned and not relied upon,
Desires can be hated and all crossed over, learning to avoid suffering one transcends and accomplishes oneself.
Abiding in sincerity do not falsely raise, hold upright conduct and empty two tongues,
Destroy the fire of anger and disperse greed, abandon vexation and understand the wisdom that sees transcendence,
Abandon delusion and do not sleep, stay far from those who are not liberated and do not associate with them,
Do not take up what is contemptible and disgusting, and what is clung to will be completely extinguished.
Do not be deceived and dragged along, and when seeing forms, do not be captivated by them.
Know that the body is illusory and do not cling to it, and it will be difficult to attain liberation by clinging to the aggregates.
Abandon thoughts of the past and do not think of them, and do not hope for future relatives.
Do not be attached to present losses and worries, and quickly run away from the four seas.
I say that craving is a great and fierce calamity, and when seen, it flows in and then doubts are restrained.
From causes and conditions, the mind is bound, and desire and defilement destroy and are difficult to escape.
Those who abandon desire are few in strength, and those who end in the world are few in number.
Abandoning without sinking and without running, the flow is already cut off without bondage.
Ridden by the power of the truths and wisdom, establishing and reaching the other shore with wisdom and without worry,
This is the dangerous and quick protection of the womb, and by diligently guarding with strength, one can reach peace.
Contemplating emptiness, the Dharma is without attachment.
Following the straight, broad, and level path, one is not attached to worldly views.
One should not consider this small body as one's own, for it does not exist. What is there to consider?
Since it cannot be obtained and does not exist, what is there to worry about that is not mine?
The roots of ignorance have been pulled out and become pure, and later sprouts will also not grow.
Having already been in the middle, do not grasp at anything. Do not need companions, abandon enemies,
And discard all names and forms. Do not be attached to thoughts of collecting.
Having already had nothing and no place, in all worlds there are no enemies.
Having already cut off all thoughts and forms, all wholesome [actions] are equal.
Having already learned and spoken the teachings, when questions come, one should respond fearlessly.
Wisdom does not come from a single source. What is sought is that which cannot be learned.
Already disgusted and abandoned without cause or condition, peacefully reaching the end of seeing.
Above, not arrogant; below, not afraid; dwelling in the middle, nothing is seen.
Dwelling in a pure place, without resentment or jealousy, although riding on views, therefore not arrogant.
